org.fluidity.foundation

Annotation Type Configuration.Property


  • @Documented
 @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Target(value={METHOD,FIELD})
public static @interface Configuration.Property
    Annotates a configuration query method to specify what property to query, what default value to return if the property is not defined, and how to process list and map typed configuration values.

    This annotation is used on interface methods that parameterize a Configuration dependency is some component.

    To handle query methods with array and parameterized Set, List or Map return types, the implementation understands JSON encoded arrays and maps, without the top level grouping characters included ('[]' and '{}'), and can convert such property values to arrays, lists, sets and maps, nested in any complexity, as long as the parameterized return type of the annotated method provides adequate information as to the expected type of any item encoded in the property value. Although the grouping and delimiter characters in the encoded property value are configurable, they aren't required to tell whether the item is a map or array since that information is already encoded in the return type of the annotated method.

    For instance, with a method returning Map<List<String>, long[]>, the following property values would be valid:

    • ""
    • "[a, b]: [1, 2, 3]"
    • "[a, b]: [1, 2, 3], c: 4, [d, e, f]: "

    • Required Element Summary

      Required Elements 
      Modifier and Type Required Element and Description
      String key
      The property key to query.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      String grouping
      For map or multidimensional collection valued properties, this string specifies the character pairs that enclose elements of one dimension.
      String ids
      Returns the property key that defines a list of other items.
      String list
      Works in conjunction with ids() to override the prefix for the individual items.
      String split
      For array or collection valued properties, this parameter defines the characters delimiting the items.
      String undefined
      Returns the default value for the property.

    • Element Detail

      • key

        public abstract String key
        The property key to query.
        Returns:
        the property key to query.

      • undefined

        public abstract String undefined
        Returns the default value for the property.
        Returns:
        the default value for the property.
        Default:
        ""

      • split

        public abstract String split
        For array or collection valued properties, this parameter defines the characters delimiting the items. The value is ignored for non collection type properties.
        Returns:
        the list of characters that delimit items of an array, collection or map valued property.
        Default:
        ",:"

      • grouping

        public abstract String grouping
        For map or multidimensional collection valued properties, this string specifies the character pairs that enclose elements of one dimension.

        For instance, @Configuration.Property(key = "…" split = ',' grouping="()") with property value "(1, 2, 3), (4, 5, 6), (7, 8, 9)" results in a 2-dimensional array that is equivalent to the following Java array initializer: { {1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}, {7, 8, 9} }.

        Returns:
        the grouping characters that surround collection elements.
        Default:
        "[]{}"

      • ids

        public abstract String ids
        Returns the property key that defines a list of other items. This is attribute is useful in cases where one property provides a list from which a list of other properties are derived, and the values of those properties should be returned as an array, collection, or map. For instance, consider the following properties: 
         item.list=1,2,3
 item.1=item1
 item.2=item1
 item.3=item1
        In the above case, you would need the following method to read the list of items as an array of String objects: 
         interface Settings {
     …
     @Configuration.Property(key = "item", ids="list")
     String[] items();
     …
 }
        Returns:
        the property key that defines a list of other items.
        Default:
        ""

      • list

        public abstract String list
        Works in conjunction with ids() to override the prefix for the individual items. For instance, let's consider the following properties: 
         item.list=1,2,3
 item.1.value=item1
 item.2.value=item1
 item.3.value=item1
        In the above case, you would need the following method to read the list of items as an array of String objects: 
         interface Settings {
     …
     @Configuration.Property(key = "item", ids="list", list="item.%%s.value")
     String[] items();
     …
 }

        Note: the placeholder used in this parameter is "%%s" to allow for interpolating the method parameters. For instance: 

         interface Settings {
     …
     @Configuration.Property(key = "item.%s", ids="list", list="item.%s.%%s.value")
     String[] items(String type);
     …
 }
        The above would allow one to query either the item.long or item.short list by calling items("long") or items("short"), respectively. 
         item.long.list=1,2,3
 item.long.1.value=item1
 item.long.2.value=item1
 item.long.3.value=item1

 item.short.list=1,2
 item.short.1.value=item1
 item.short.2.value=item1
        In the above case, you would need the following method to read the list of items as an array of String objects:
        Returns:
        the property key pattern for individual items in a list; defaults to key().concat(".%%s").
        Default:
        ""
